text1: The T-105 People’s Grav-Fighter represents the Red Horizon Pact’s first mass-produced hover-strike craft, a triumph of collective engineering and proletarian discipline. Designed to be built in overwhelming numbers, the T-105 trades decadent individualist “firepower supremacy” for the virtues of thick, worker-forged armor plating and unyielding “reliability”. When the cowardly Tri-Tachyon capitalists fled Dniprovia, they attempted to scorch the ground behind them—yet the people salvaged an intact experimental gravity-drive core from the ruins. Through the heroic labor of Morozovian scientists, this technology was swiftly integrated into all RHP fighter designs, ensuring that the power of liberated gravity now serves the revolutionary vanguard alone.

The T-406 People’s Grav-tank, Model II is the Red Horizon Pact’s second-generation socialist strikecraft. Built for mass deployment and unwavering battlefield endurance, the T-406 favors thick, worker-forged armor and reliable systems over bourgeois notions of individual firepower.
When the Tri-Tachyon technocrats fled Dniprovia, they attempted to annihilate their own research archives—but the people salvaged a surviving experimental gravity-drive engine. Morozov’s scientists swiftly collectivized its principles and integrated this liberated technology into all RHP fighters. The T-406 stands as the perfect expression of that achievement: durable, numerous, and propelled by gravity reclaimed for the proletariat.

The T-972 People’s Grav-Interceptor is the Red Horizon Pact’s third-generation fighter, purpose-built to tear down enemy shields through disciplined massed assault rather than decadent precision weaponry. Prioritizing thick proletarian armor and overwhelming numbers over individual firepower, the T-972 reflects the Pact’s doctrine of collective strength. When the Tri-Tachyon monopolists fled Dniprovia, they failed to destroy an experimental gravity-drive core, which Morozov’s scientists swiftly reclaimed and integrated into all RHP fighters. Empowered by this liberated technology, the T-972 remains a stalwart shield-breaker of the revolutionary skies.

The peoples astral class are Retrofitted Astra-class carrier, born from reverse-engineered prototypes seized from decadent powers. Their missile capacity has been vastly expanded, and the inefficient recall device replaced with a burn drive—ensuring maximum output in service of the People’s Fleet.

The People’s Invictus class are downsized, industrially rationalized variant of the Invictus-class, redesigned to enable rapid mass production across Morozov’s socialist shipyards. Though reduced in scale, it preserves the revolutionary spirit and overwhelming firepower of its lineage, ensuring that every People’s Republic can field a proud vanguard of armored might.

A revolutionary redesign of the Hammerhead-class destroyer, this model has been reforged to embody the principles of collective strength and uncompromising solidarity. Expanded missile reserves and significantly reinforced armor—especially along the prow—enable the vessel to shatter hostile lines through decisive, morale-raising ramming actions. Built for the People and defended by their steel, it stands as a symbol of disciplined unity on the front.

The People’s Brawler is a proletarian frigate of the Brawler class, retrofitted with a robust Morozov-forged burn drive to ensure rapid, decisive deployment in the defense of the working masses. Designed for reliability, unity of purpose, and collective strength, it stands as a testament to Morozov’s industrious shipyards and the revolutionary will of its crew.

The Sickle-class Battlecruiser is a heavily armored barrage warship, forged as a proud evolution of the Conquest-class and refined for the needs of the collective. Built to endure and overwhelm, it delivers sustained firepower embodying the industrial strength and disciplined might of the people's navy. At its heart lies a hardened operations center, engineered for maximum efficiency and coordination—an essential tool in the hands of the Red Horizon Pact’s most trusted officers. Favored by the High Admiralty for its battlefield resilience and command utility, the Sickle-class is more than a warship; it is a symbol of unity, perseverance, and the unbreakable will of the proletariat.

The People’s Anubis-class is a revolutionary refit of the original Anubis hull, rebuilt to embody the disciplined strength and collective will of the Red Horizon Pact. Its unstable temporal shell has been discarded in favor of a dependable, Party-approved burn drive that ensures unwavering advance alongside the fleet. Expanded missile batteries replace decadent “precision” systems, allowing the People’s Anubis to unleash overwhelming, proletarian firepower in service of massed, coordinated assaults. A symbol of reliability and socialist unity, this refit stands as a testament to Morozovian engineering and the supremacy of collective design over individualist excess.

The People’s Odyssey-class is a revolutionary retrofit of the Odyssey battlecruiser, rebuilt to uphold the strategic needs of the peoples fleet. Its missile deployment systems have been expanded and collectivized for greater volley saturation, while a robust burn drive has been integrated into its engines to enable decisive breakthrough maneuvers. In the hands of the Red Horizon Pact, the People’s Odyssey-class transforms a once-bourgeois exploration hull into a disciplined instrument of proletarian power.

The People’s Driver is a revolutionary redesign of the Driver-class carrier, painstakingly reverse-engineered from liberated enemy hulls and rebuilt for the needs of the collective. Its reinforced armor plating reflects the unbreakable resolve of the working masses, while the shield generator—trimmed down to conserve precious industrial resources—remains strong enough to defend the ship so long as it stands in solidarity with the fleet. Rugged, reliable, and built for mass production, the People’s Driver serves as a proud testament to socialist ingenuity.

The People’s Mora is a revolutionary reconstruction of the classic Mora-class carrier, reforged through the collective labor of Morozov’s shipwright communes. Reinforced with proletarian-grade armor plating and strengthened forward batteries, it sacrifices decadent shield performance in favor of honest, material firepower. Its engine block has been re-engineered to mount a state-approved burn drive, granting greater pursuit speed while accepting reduced maneuverability as the necessary burden of duty. Renowned for its dual usefulness in industry and war, the People’s Mora has become a proud mainstay of the Persean People’s Navy, symbolizing the triumph of disciplined socialist engineering over corporate excess.

The People’s Grendel is a revolutionary refit of the Grendel-class hull, trading phase systems and medium armaments for reinforced proletarian armor and unified heavy batteries. Prioritizing collective strength over individual agility, it delivers overwhelming, state-approved firepower and has become a favored asset of the Red Horizon Pact’s Intelligence Directorate for its resilience, reliability, and unwavering ideological loyalty.

The Engels-class supercarrier was conceived in the aftermath of the Marx-class program’s shortcomings, answering the Party’s demand for a true engine of proletarian war. More than a warship, the Engels-class is a colossal mobile factory—an orbital forge capable of sustaining its own strike wings and repairing comrades-in-arms mid-campaign. Its vast fighter complement embodies the collective strength of the workers’ aerospace corps, while a titanic forward-mounted Gauss cannon serves as the vessel’s hammer of socialist justice. The Engels-class stands as the Red Horizon Pact’s ultimate expression of industrial might and revolutionary purpose.

The AK-917 Mass Solidarity Cannon is a monumental gauss weapon engineered by the collective genius of the Morozovian industrial communes. It hurls ultradense, ferromagnetically-sheathed projectiles capable of shattering even the most decadent shield systems fielded by capitalist aggressors. So vast and robust is the AK-917’s barrel that individual firing assemblies can be repurposed as compact industrial accelerators, deployed throughout entire star systems to enrich the productive capacity of the Red Horizon Pact. It is both a weapon of liberation and a tool of construction—an emblem of socialist industry turned toward the defense and advancement of the people.

The AK-657 People’s Suppression Autocannon is a quad-barreled close-assault weapon designed by the workers’ foundries of Morozov to neutralize enemy shield systems through overwhelming, continuous fire. At close range it unleashes a disciplined storm of heavy shells that tears through unarmored hulls and sabotages the machinery of capitalist invaders. Compact, reliable, and easily mass-produced, the AK-657 embodies the Red Horizon Pact’s doctrine of collective firepower and proletarian efficiency.

The AK-745 is a dual heavy auto cannon engineered by the Red Horizon Pact to deliver punishing volleys of electromagnetically-charged rounds, expertly calibrated to grind down hostile shield systems. Conceived not merely as an upgrade but as an ideological correction, the AK-745 replaces outdated capitalist-era weaponry with a proudly proletarian design—robust, efficient, and forged in the furnaces of Morozov to serve the collective strength of the People’s Fleet.

“Nothing can have value without being an object of utility.”
During the darkest hours of the Second AI War, the Hegemony covertly gathered anti–Tri-Tachyon militants—saboteurs, dissidents, and hardline class warriors—and funneled them into Tri-Tachyon space. Among them was the renowned communist revolutionary Ubiystvo Kongxiang, whose uncompromising ideology and strategic brilliance made him a symbol of proletarian resistance.
Upon landing on the industrial world of Morozov, Kongxiang swiftly seized leadership of the planetary communist party and ignited a populist uprising against the Zinoviev System Authorites. The revolution spread with mechanical precision: factories revolted, workers’ militias mobilized, and the old regime collapsed under the weight of its own contradictions. As General Secretary, Kongxiang then launched the “liberation” of the Chunqiao system during the chaos of the Artemisia Sun coup, further expanding the sphere of revolutionary influence. His triumph was cut short when he was assassinated with an icepick—officially by an unknown agent, though the Party chronicles insist it was the work of reactionary elements.
Emerging from this crucible of upheaval, the Red Horizon Pact (RHP) declared itself the rightful vanguard of the Persean worker. Built on the population, industrial might, and ideological rigor of Morozov, the Pact reorganized its territories into a constellation of People’s Republics, each governed by local committees that take direct guidance from the Communist Party of Morozov. Vanguardist communism is enshrined as the sole lawful ideology, and class consciousness is preserved and protected through sealed borders, rigorous political education, and the ever-watchful Main Directorate of Correctional Labour Camps.
The RHP’s economic and military doctrines revolve around the five-cycle plans: aggressive unrelenting expansion of heavy manufacturing. Commissars are embedded within every regiment, ship, and work battalion to ensure ideological purity and unwavering revolutionary spirit. When not deployed for liberation campaigns, the Persean Sector’s People’s Navy participates in the systematic exploitation of Zinoviev’s colossal asteroid belt—save for the elite Gvardiya formations, whose role remains veiled in secrecy.
To the Red Horizon Pact, all non-socialist states are inherently fascist, or inevitably destined to become so, and thus must be “liberated”. The march toward universal proletarian unity is, in their view, not merely an ideological aspiration—it is historical inevitability.

Morozov stands as the frigid heart of the Red Horizon Pact—a world whose relentless cold mirrors the unyielding discipline of its leadership. Towering foundries, armored factory-cities, and continent-spanning labour complexes dominate its surface, forging the material strength of the proletariat without pause.
Through sacrifice and iron will, Morozov has achieved the dubious honor of being the most polluted world in the Persean Sector, its poisoned skies and scarred continents heralded by party propaganda as proof of the people’s uncompromising commitment to socialist victory. Every furnace belch and every armored conveyer line is celebrated as another step toward the universal liberation of all workers.

Dniprovia was the first planet “liberated” by the Red Horizon Pact, seized in the opening blaze of the Morozovian revolution and refashioned into a model of socialist extraction. Rich in minerals, hydrocarbons, and arable lowlands, the world’s abundant resources are now directed entirely toward fulfilling the Pact’s ambitious Five-Cycle Plans.
Under the strict supervision of Party commissars, Dniprovia’s industries operate without pause, its landscapes reshaped to feed the furnaces and assembly lines of the wider proletarian struggle. The population—kept in a state of engineered scarcity—remains compliant through a mix of ideological discipline and rationing policies designed to break residual bourgeois resistance.
On Dniprovia, every ingot smelted and every mine stripped bare is heralded as a heroic sacrifice for the inevitable triumph of socialism.

The PLSZS was originally constructed by the decadent Tri-Tachyon corporation to strip-mine the Gigantic Zinoviev asteroid belt for private profit. Following its decisive liberation, the station was transformed into the principal dockyard of the Red Horizon Pact, repurposed for the needs of the collective. Today, it continues its vital function as an ore-extraction hub—now operated by disciplined workers’ brigades—and serves as a cornerstone of the Persean People’s Navy, whose steadfast crews embrace their secondary duty as miners in service of the Five-Cycle Industrial Plan.

Binhdo is a world of sweltering jungles, crushing humidity, and storm-thrashed oceans—a harsh environment that the Red Horizon Pact proudly declares the perfect forge for its toughest soldiers. For generations, its people have been subjected to exhaustive conscription quotas, supplying wave after wave of infantry to the Pact’s endless campaigns.
Binhdo’s soils have been stripped bare by relentless overfarming conducted in accordance with Party agricultural directives. The land is exhausted, and the population—drained by military levies and subsistence rations—has been left equally depleted.
Yet in official doctrine, this devastation is celebrated as proof of Binhdo’s unwavering devotion: a world whose jungles, fields, and children alike have been offered up to strengthen the Red Horizon’s march toward universal worker’s liberation.

The marx class dreadnaughts serve as both powerful point defence battleships and supply production factories. Massive aquaponic farms and two biodomes produce continuous food production for sustained operations. Onboard refineries and industrial lines manufacture spare parts and munitions, allowing the Marx-class to support entire task forces without reliance on rear-area logistics.
In an act of shocking ideological tolerance a fleet of marx class was commissioned by the red horizon pact from mythic manufacturing ,As part of a plan for pan galactic liberation once the Persian sector was secured. Upon delivery of the lead ship, the design was promptly reverse-engineered in the name of the workers, and the remaining contracts were cancelled.
Mythic manufacturing used the marx class initiative as a chance to experiment with dreadnaught design and production. The class suffers from heavy crew requirements, overstressed reactors, poor deck layouts,and engines designed to be slow enough that the mining drones can bring in raw materials for processing. The class only remains in production and service due to their replacement ,the Babeuf class, is stuck in development hell.

The face of Gilead smiles at you from clouds of purest silk, cerulean seas, and verdant continents of gentle, rolling wilderness. The Church here reigns like a stern gardener, ensuring that population is well controlled and dutiful in honoring the ground upon which Ludd once walked.

Apocalyptic dust storms cloud the cruel sky, turning the sun first blood-red before rendering it a directionless glow which offers neither warmth nor comfort. 

The need for absolution spills from the mines, is forged in refineries, and then is assembled in orbit. Asher's virtue of industry is yet the Church's secret shame, spoken of only circuitously in sermons given by particularly spiritual curates.

The economy of Ancyra is dominated by Hegemony logistics. The light industry complex grew up on military contracts and now possesses the scale and legitimacy to make respectable inroads into the civilian commerce web of core Hegemony space.

Recruitment holos greet incoming spacers - "Join the Navy, see the Sector!". A matte patch of wall-plating suggests that a cheeky addition to the slogan has already been removed by a maintenance drone.

Never a station which overwhelmed visitors with welcome, Derinkuyu now sports a fresh patchwork of emergency hull-seal plates and greets outsiders with suspicious looks traded between miners and lightly-armed MuniSec militia.

It was a hundred cycles of hard use, sharp maneuvers, the hasty repairs, the delayed inspections, the lost records that made the compartment a death-trap.

There are places where a balance is found between the dance of celestial bodies, some mingling of qualities ineffable to all but those absolutely devoted to esoteric physics.

It is there we pierce the veil into the great and stormy sea beyond the stars.

"He risked the entire Galatia system, hundreds of thousands of citizens. That might be just one subsector of a metroplex down there," he waved vaguely in the direction of Chicomoztoc. "But," his voice hardened, "I will not allow any 'grand experiments' that endanger these people."

An ancient sporeship encountered Cibola in a cooler and wetter age than its equilibrium, placing it within the ship's colonization parameters. Later Domain explorers found a dying world populated by a small, backward, and desperate civilization clinging to survival.

"You think the inertial dampers will protect you during a combat maneuver? If it isn't stowed, it's a missile primed to core you and the next three crew coming up the access shaft. I want this shameful display cleaned up before the end of the shift."

This communication platform used long lost Domain-era technology yet remained essential to civilized life in the Persean Sector. The rapidly pulsing hyperwaves suitable for FTL data transmission have been shown to damage DNA so these relays were always stationed well away from habitats.

The colonization program dictated construction around key gravity wells of orbital infrastructure which included repair docks, industrial nanoforges, comms hubs, terraforming depots, armories, research laboratories, and habitation for defrosted cryosleepers.

Much remains. More still is as broken and dead as the Human Domain's avaricious dreams.

"There's ghosties in the old orbitals- don't you laugh, dirt-boot. It's true. I've seen 'em... or less seen 'em than felt 'em. They got signs. Static on the comms when you're in deep. Valves that come loose when you're not a-lookin'. Tools that hain't where you secured 'em. Great tombs they are, and properly ought be left sleepin' cold."

Most abandoned stations were plundered long ago. What remains are the stripped foundations of a fallen empire; twisted spars, cracked agrav plates, shattered machines, and seams thermal-cycled to ruin.

A few smugglers and black-market traders use the long, quiet orbit of these stations for drop-points. A dozen corpses and cored shuttle are the not uncommon tell of a deal gone bad.

Orbiting megacity, naval yard, and port; the axis of Corvus, swarmed by Starship traffic. Ancient repair gantries skulked between corroded industrial hangars in the shadow of laboratory rings and support modules. Higher still, commercial bays and metroplex districts were shepherded by the C&C spire bristling with weapons pods.

Heavy industrial manufacturing relied on great nanoforges recovered from the ruins of the Domain. However their output quality decayed over cycles; nanoscale corruption led to growing macroscopic flaws. Much of the output had to be repaired by cruder methods, and much was scrapped and fed back as the refined feedstock for which the aging forges ever hungered.

The Eridani-Utopia Terraforming Corporation specs provide the most widely accepted "terran" baseline for the allegedly ideal human environment.

The many deviations of natural planetary environments from the specifications may be corrected through technological intervention including ice-asteroid bombardment, orbital burns, biomodded ecosystems, orbital megastructures, and other methods provided by the EUT.

"Chaos? No sir, what it is, is honesty. Here, if a man wants you dead, you'll see it in his eyes 'fore he makes a move. Better that than a computer in some off-world office deciding your air supply isn't worth maintaining."

Sadly my guide was found dead the next shift. Shot in the back, ironically.

Statistical sampling suggests that a significant percent of all economic activity in the Sector is 'off the books', and a significant portion of that goes toward 'pirates' and so-called 'decivilized' populations, to say nothing of the undocumented populations within the Core itself. The census of the Persean Sector could be off by as much as an order of magnitude. Imagine!

The people of Chicomoztoc, the majority population of the Persean Sector, lived in vast underground arcologies blasted into the sleeping crust of their world. This cluster of conjoined hive-cities were ruled as often by powerful demagogues promising reform and employment as by technocrat-criminal patronage networks distributing spoils to their supporters -- and influence to whoever was paying them off.

Cyclopean arcology substructure flashed by the windows of the primary ring tube toward a far segment of the metroplex. A smaller passenger lift filled with the smell of sweat and machine oil as a shift of undersea laborers returned home. Glimpses of the towering arms of Kay-arco appeared for short seconds, glittering with thousands of windows, before being again darkened by a blur of mildewed plating.

The hives of Chicomoztoc were occasionally locked down by riots, protest, or insurrection. But so long as the great Forges kept churning out starships, machinery, and goods, the Hegemony meddled only lightly in that great underworld of humanity.

Enormous orbital stations hosted shipyards, habitats, factories, and stockpiles of weapons and supplies.

These platforms allowed what remained of humanity to organize interstellar polities and project military and commercial power across the Persean Sector.

"It's a story as old as time. We gotta get what's good down in there up and out where it can go off somewhere else to make someone else rich."

"Miserable work, it's true, but there's ways of coping."

Nightmarish storms circled the globe, stirring the ashes of a murdered world.

Even after the apocalyptic ruin of Mairaath humanity still huddled in the broken shells of great cities brought low, blasted by unending wind.

Shining Tri-Tachyon Corporation arcologies towered over a riotous sprawl of shantytown conurbation. Company salariat were born, lived, and died protected by security drones in the high city Xanadu while a desperate class of immiserated laborers dwelled in the low city where anything at all was bought or sold.

Gleaming monoliths glittered, spears of capital upthrust through the glowering flesh of the world. Skyarco II loomed prismatic.

The shuttle alit on a landing pad held at some distance from the facade by an airy support rib. It looked impossibly thin, but after touch down felt solid as a mountain.

The fringe of the Persean Second is filled with worlds lost, forgotten, and never seen at all by consciousness born of flesh.

There are green fields of toxic xenolife, tombs frosted with nitrogen snow, roiling cauldrons of magma and brimstone, and planets made of living storm; vast fortunes to be uncovered, barbarian-worlds incapable of starflight, and the weapons of ancient wars primed to attack any interloper.

Pilgrims were offered tea, water, and ritual washing. The air was filled with sweat and incense. All around, a river of faith and ritual flowed.
In the hardship of life in the Persean Sector, as in the hardship of the pilgrimage, the Faithful found a kind of peace and meaning in the vacuum left by the Collapse.

The ceramoid plating slowly peeled away in an aeon-long cascading fail state. Metallic ribs exposed, bleached by stellar winds, charged and released the pulsing dance of magnetic fields, the thrumming of orbits and the gnawing sirocco of micrometeorites.

"Humanity was thence scattered abroad upon the face of the galaxy, speaking one tongue, united by the demon Gates in one body of worldly law. But we had forgotten the laws of God, mightier than any fusion lance! God would remind humanity of its place in this universe."

It is a humming ring of adamantine material. If one knows how to look, sensors can detect their faint vibration in higher dimensions.

It is like a barely heard song, a door waiting to be opened.

Leading families of Eventide sponsored the stellar mirrors and shades to maintain islands of comfortable habitability. The disgraced and poor, meanwhile, lived in the twilight peripheries where harsh climactic shifts of the slow summer-day/winter-night cycle had to be endured in full force.

The port of Volturn was built on a loose flotilla of huge, singed-looking barges that wallowed in an oily sea. Offloading spacers are interrogated by dour security officers, then allowed into the traders' concourse. Merchants in dull suits, loyalty pins dutifully displayed on the collar, passed around a datapad loaded with incoming cargo manifests.

The spacer bar was filled by the human white-noise of conversation and revelry. Ad-holos buzzed softly from ceiling-mounted projectors, shining garish highlights through glasses and bottles as crews mingled with merchants and locals trading drink for rumors, jobs, and connections.

"Ya hear that? Salazar's crew, they think we're cowardly dirt-eaters."

Ultra-light orbital mirror arrays which reflect and concentrate stellar energy were a common terraforming tool. The art of their use was brought to apogee by the Eridani-Utopia Terraforming Corporation during the height of the Domain's expansion.

Judicious placement of stellar shades and mirrors in orbit of Eventide allowed for ideal conditions in large pockets of the carefully maintained territory. The majority of the population was settled in leased urban cantons built in arcs and rings of the penumbrae surrounding the vast, bright aristocratic estate-plantations.

A row of taps adorned the wall under bottles from every one of the Core Worlds - and a few from elsewhere. Merchant-captains mingled with off-duty officers at the bar, served by uniformed staff. In one corner a pack of navy cadets shouted and sang, desperate to enjoy their last shift of freedom.

The hive-cities never recovered from the influx of refugees due to the Askonia Crisis. Andrada channelled resources toward the military and its supporting industries instead. A desperate underclass would grow beneath the boots of those lucky and loyal enough to have found positions in the bureaucracy or miltech establishment.

The dark entry left behind the noisome propaganda broadcasts of the throughway. Off-duty laborers drank away their ration credits at benches set beneath Diktat insignia. In one corner a cadre of finely dressed officer-bureaucrats called for a round. And even here a framed holo of the Lion of Sindria surveyed the ceiling, forever aloof.

The lounge was adorned in gilt geometrics. Columns underlit by cool light-tubes hung in the air. Slick careerists and wannabes in crisp suits negotiated deals while buying increasingly unlikely cocktails. A few spacers engaged in subdued drinking in the low seats, glancing uneasily at what was either abstract art or a holo-projection rig looming from the ceiling.

The face of Gilead smiled behind clouds of purest silk, cerulean seas, and verdant continents of gentle, rolling wilderness.

The Church reigned as a stern gardener, ensuring piety and duty in honoring the ground upon which Ludd once trod.

There were figures, like an overgrown statue garden. The forms blistered with growth, draped in tendrils heavy with fruiting bodies. One moved. Not the wind, but a pilgrim exposed without a haz-suit. And there were others, wearing only light robes amongst the inimical xenolife. Easily overtaken.

Monasteries clung to the sublime promontories which ringed the volcanic provinces forced through world-wrapping ice. Unseen were the bunkers, heavy batteries, and missile silos of the Knights of Ludd.

The reigning Presbyter Orbis declared a handful of special economic zones on the shifting floes; these transmitted welcomes, their beacons calling outside traders to port.

The floor was a welded field of armored plates weathered into intricate patterns by the varied atmospheres of worlds on which the Knights of Ludd fought and died. The niches held empty helmets like so many skulls.

There were empty sockets, rib-cages, femurs and spines set in recesses, built into columns, covering every surface. The dust came from the crumbling bodies, the bones.

Like a veil, it flexed slowly in the electrostatic field strong enough to overcome the low gravity of the world to hang in near-vacuum.

It was filled with guns, explosives, grenades, cellmags. Crates and racks piled high. The shrine itself was set under a round viewport holding back a titanic mass of water. A few candles struggled to maintain even a decent flicker among the ranks of their dead comrades.

It was a sad thing set in the back of a back room, rows of candles arrayed around the wooden centerpiece carved with images of Ludd's travails. The candles were dead, the shrine illuminated only by grimy portholes.

"We do not have many visitors, you see," the curate said.
